title: Error: 'import' and 'export' may appear only with 'sourceType: module', When running sls deploy
body:
### Are you certain it's a bug?

- [x] Yes, it looks like a bug

### Is the issue caused by a plugin?

- [X] It is not a plugin issue

### Are you using the latest v3 release?

- [X] Yes, I'm using the latest v3 release

### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched existing issues, it hasn't been reported yet

### Issue description

running a deploy throws an Error: 'import' and 'export' may appear only with 'sourceType: module'.

Trying setting "sourceType" to "module" and it didn't work.

### Service configuration (serverless.yml) content

```yaml
service: nest-serverless-lambda

plugins:
 - 'serverless-plugin-typescript'
 - serverless-plugin-optimize
 - serverless-offline
 - serverless-webpack

provider:
 name: aws
 runtime: nodejs14.x

functions:
 oa-staging-backend:
   handler: packages/backend/src/app/lambda.handler
   events:
     - http:
         method: any
         path: /{any+}
```


### Command name and used flags

sls deploy --verbose --debug "*"

### Command output

author: basselabbara

comments.body: @basselabbara this looks as problem related to one of the used plugins. Please report at given plugin repository
@medikoo Can you tell which plugin?
@basselabbara unfortunately not
@basselabbara try it without serverless-plugin-optimize
@ahmadissa I already had to do it that way and it worked so I created an issue on the plugin's issue page. So far no response so I guess I'm gonna have to move on without optimize.

If you want to use axios while using optimization, you can exclude the relevant modules from optimization.
ex:
```
custom:
  optimize:
    external:
      [
        'axios',
        'form-data',
        'combined-stream',
        'delayed-stream',
        'mime-types',
        'mime-db',
        'asynckit',
        'proxy-from-env',
        'follow-redirects',
      ]
    includePaths:
      [
        'node_modules/axios',
        'node_modules/form-data',
        'node_modules/combined-stream',
        'node_modules/delayed-stream',
        'node_modules/mime-types',
        'node_modules/mime-db',
        'node_modules/asynckit',
        'node_modules/proxy-from-env',
        'node_modules/follow-redirects',
      ]
```

satisfaction_conditions: Resolve ES6 module syntax compatibility during deployment optimization
Maintain TypeScript compilation while resolving module format conflicts
Handle third-party module dependencies requiring ES6 syntax
Allow continued use of optimization plugins when possible

title: Migrating from x86_64 to arm64 Graviton2 processor not updated
body:
### Are you certain it's a bug?

- [X] Yes, it looks like a bug

### Is the issue caused by a plugin?

- [X] It is not a plugin issue

### Are you using the latest version?

- [X] Yes, I'm using the latest version

### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched existing issues, it hasn't been reported yet

### Issue description

We tried to migrate our development env's lambda workload from x86_64 to arm64 Graviton2 processor using a serverless framework. serverless deployment was successful but the processor configuration was not changed. still it was using x86 processor. When I tried to change it manually on the AWS console, it was saying 
```
If the function uses a compiled language, or the function size exceeds the code editor storage limit (3 MB), you must upload a .zip file archive (or .jar file) when you change the architecture. Uploading a new .zip file package overwrites the existing code.
```
 Is there any alternative way to override this? or how to change/migrate the processor without recreating/rebuilding the code?

```
provider:
  name: aws
  runtime: nodejs12.x
  timeout: 90
  memorySize: 1024
  tracing: ture
  architecture: arm64
```

FYI: if the code is less than 3MB and if it is not a zip file, I can change the processor using `sls deploy`

### Service configuration (serverless.yml) content

```yaml
N/A
```


### Command name and used flags

N/A

### Command output

```shell
serverless --deploy --stage flux
```


### Environment information

```shell
sh-4.2# serverless --version
Framework Core: 2.18.0
Plugin: 4.4.2
SDK: 2.3.2
Components: 3.4.6
sh-4.2#
```
author: pbalajiips

comments.body:
@medikoo Thanks a lot!!!, with recent version i can update the processors arch. 

#sls --version 
Framework Core: 3.17.0
Plugin: 6.2.2
SDK: 4.3.2

satisfaction_conditions: Solution must enable architecture change without requiring code rebuild/recreation
Must work with Serverless Framework configuration
Must address version compatibility issues
Ensure architecture setting propagates correctly to AWS
Avoid manual AWS console interventions

title: Unable to configure provisioned concurrency 0
body:
<!--
Q1: Describe the problem (use case) that needs to be solved:
-->

When using `configValidationMode: error` and provisioned concurrency is set to 0 for some function, an error is thrown requiring:
```
Configuration error at 'functions.authorizer.provisionedConcurrency': should be >= 1
```

### Use case description

This would be useful in cases where provisioned concurrency is only desired for certain stage deployments.  It allows the provisioned concurrency configuration to be conditional.

<!--
Q2: Propose a solution (e.g. provide configuration example)
-->

### Proposed solution

Allow provisioned concurrency 0 - it currently works without `configValidationMode: error`, which is useful in cases where provisioned currency is only desired for certain stage deployments.  It allows the provisioned concurrency configuration to be conditional.

```
functions:
  authorizer:
    handler: handler
    provisionedConcurrency: ${self:custom.config.authorizer-provisioned-concurrency}
```
author: jackmuskopf

comments.body: @jackmuskopf if you don't want to setup `provisionedConcurrency` but for some technical reason need to keep property in configuration, simply set it to `null`

@medikoo Using `null` works with `configValidationMode: error` but leads me to a different concern: using `null` fails with

```
  Cannot resolve serverless.yml: Variables resolution errored with:
    - Cannot resolve variable at "functions.authorizer.provisionedConcurrency": Value not found at "self" 
source
```

when using `variablesResolutionMode: 20210326`, which like `configValidationMode: error` looks like it will become default in the next major release.  Maybe I can use `configValidationMode: warn` after the next major release.

satisfaction_conditions: Allow conditional configuration of provisioned concurrency without validation errors
Support null values in variable resolution without errors
Maintain compatibility with upcoming configuration validation defaults
Enable stage-specific provisioning configurations

title: v1.67.0 Could not unzip uploaded file
body:
# Bug Report

## Description

1. What did you do: AWS, nodejs HTTP API with events
1. What happened?:  CustomDashresourceDashapigwDashcwDashroleLambdaFunction - Could not unzip uploaded file
1. What should've happened?: Success deploy
1. What's the content of your `serverless.yml` file?
```yml
app: myapp
org: myorg
service: myservice

provider:
  name: aws
  runtime: nodejs12.x

functions:
  api:
    handler: handler.http
    events:
      - http:
          path: /packages/{packages}
          method: post
```

It works with v1.66.0.
- #12345
author: ianberdin

comments.body: Same issue here, but it works on **1.67.3** though
@ianberdin do you still observe the issue with latest version? What OS are you on?

Hi, I will check later

---

1.6.8 perfectly works.
Thank you 👍

satisfaction_conditions: Identifies a Serverless Framework version where the deployment zip file error is resolved
Confirms compatibility with AWS Node.js HTTP API deployments
Validates successful deployment without zip corruption issues

title: Ignore 200 CF resource limit
body:
Hello,

Would it be possible to ignore the CF resource limit validation? I’ve managed to increase the limit from 200 to 500 resources (through AWS support), but the deploy still fails because it looks like the framework also validates locally the number of resources in a stack.

Thank you.
author: celicoo

comments.body:
@celicoo 200 resources per stack is a fixed, not adjustable, limit on AWS grounds (also I don't think framework implies any extra validation on that).

I believe you've increased some other limit (e.g. maximum number of stacks)
@medikoo you're right. Sorry for not replying earlier.

satisfaction_conditions: Clarification that AWS CloudFormation's 200-resource limit is fixed and not adjustable
Confirmation that the framework does not implement additional resource count validation
Differentiation between stack resource limits and other AWS service quotas

title: Turn of SLS_DEBUG
body:
This is probably a super simple issue to be resolved, but I can't turn off SLS_DEBUG to save my life. I turned it on by submitting `export SLS_DEBUG=*` via terminal. I have tried to use `export SLS_DEBUG=false` but that doesn't prevent the logs from continuing. How do I resolve this? It has to be easier than the amount of time I have spent trying to figure this out.

Thanks.
author: chasebleyl

comments.body:
@chasebleyl I guess `unset` is the command that you're looking for 😄 

Try this:
```bash
unset SLS_DEBUG
```

Let me know if it helps.
That was it! Thank you.

satisfaction_conditions: Completely removes the SLS_DEBUG environment variable rather than just changing its value
Provides a method to reverse the initial environment variable assignment
Works in the same context/scope where the variable was originally set

title: Serverless Error ---------------------------------------        An error occurred while provisioning your stack: S3BucketServerlesschatbotdevuploadsyourinitialshere      - serverless-chatbot-dev-uploads-your-initials-here      already exists.
body:
I've got this issue:
  Serverless Error ---------------------------------------
 
     An error occurred while provisioning your stack: S3BucketServerlesschatbotdevuploadsyourinitialshere
     - serverless-chatbot-dev-uploads-your-initials-here
     already exists.

Any ideas?
author: rachelwu11

comments.body:
Hi @rachelwu11 

Have you tried renaming your stack and running `serverless deploy` again?

Hey @RafalWilinski , @DavidWells he helped me out. If the custom variable was called uploadBucket, then there was a conflict. so i've renamed it to be bucket, and it worked. Thanks a lot. :)
      
     UPLOAD_BUCKET: ${self:custom.bucket
      bucket: ${self:service}-${self:provider.stage}-uploads-xw

satisfaction_conditions: Resolve S3 bucket naming conflicts during deployment
Modify resource identifiers to incorporate dynamic/unique elements
Handle variable naming conflicts in serverless configuration
Ensure environment-specific resource isolation

title: Having an event only for prod stage
body:
# This is a Bug Report

## Description

I'm would like to use a schedule event on a function but only on the production stage. I'm trying to do something like that : 

    functions:
        myfunction:
            handler: myfunction.handler
                stage: production
                    events:
                         - schedule: cron(0 15 * * ? *)

Is there a way to do that ? Thanks a lot 

## Additional Data

* ***Serverless Framework Version you're using***: 1.5.1
* ***Operating System***: OS X 10.12
author: chrishiste

comments.body: I believe you could use the variable system to load nothing into events for every stage other than production.

Ok thanks a lot ! I'm gonna check it out

---

Hello again, I've been trying to use the variable system but even though it seems really powerful I couldn't find a way to do what you said. It seems that there is no way to do an if statement like : 
if ${opt:stage} == 'prod', I could also do it from JS and references it like they show in the doc but then I don't know which stage I'm deploying too. Did you already do something similar ? Sorry, I'm fairly new to Serverless

@chrishiste I don't have time to test it at the moment but it will look something like:

```yaml
custom:
  stage: "${opt:stage, self:provider.stage}"
  prod:
    schedule:
       - schedule: cron(0 15 * * ? *)
  dev:
    schedule:

functions:
    myfunction:
        handler: myfunction.handler
            stage: production
                events: ${self:custom.${self:custom.stage}.schedule}        
```

That way it loads `custom.prod.schedule` when you're on deploying to production and `custom.dev.schedule` when you're deploying to development.

THANKS A LOT! I didn't really understood the variable system until now

If anyone is looking to do something similar that's how I did it : 

```yaml
custom:
  stage: "${opt:stage, self:provider.stage}"
    prod:
      schedule: cron(0 15 * * ? *)
   dev:
      schedule:

functions:
   myFunction:
     handler: myFunction.handler
     events:
       - schedule: ${self:custom.${self:custom.stage}.schedule}
```

Just make sure you pass "--stage" and not "-s"
Nice! Thanks for helping and thanks for posting the solution so that others can use it as well!
Maybe this could be added to the main schedule documentation, I think it is a quite common use case to only have the schedular running for the production lambda.

Could also use `enabled` to turn them on or off for different stages

```
functions:
  fetch:
    handler: handler.fetch
    events:
    - schedule:
        rate: rate(1 minute)
        enabled: ${self:custom.scheduleEnabled.${self:provider.stage}}

custom:
  scheduleEnabled:
    prod: true
    dev: false
    local: false
```

> Could also use `enabled` to turn them on or off for different stages
> 
> ```
> functions:
>   fetch:
>     handler: handler.fetch
>     events:
>     - schedule:
>         rate: rate(1 minute)
>         enabled: ${self:custom.scheduleEnabled.${self:provider.stage}}
> 
> custom:
>   scheduleEnabled:
>     prod: true
>     dev: false
>     local: false
> ```

Is this confirmed to work, with booleans? Because it seems that booleans are not allowed, giving `Trying to populate non string value into a string...` error.

@juanilarregui I have a similar issue when I write `enabled: false` it does deploy but I can see that the CloudWatch event is still enabled in the AWS Console. 

Have you found a way to make it work?
I dont seem to get any issues with the code I posted above. Could you post a copy of what your doing?

> Could also use `enabled` to turn them on or off for different stages
> 
> ```
> functions:
>   fetch:
>     handler: handler.fetch
>     events:
>     - schedule:
>         rate: rate(1 minute)
>         enabled: ${self:custom.scheduleEnabled.${self:provider.stage}}
> 
> custom:
>   scheduleEnabled:
>     prod: true
>     dev: false
>     local: false
> ```

This doesn't disable the schedule, it deploys though.
deleted

satisfaction_conditions: Conditionally enable schedule events based on deployment stage
Use Serverless Framework's variable system for stage-aware configuration
Avoid hardcoding stage names in event configurations
Validate configuration works across Serverless versions
Provide clear stage-based toggling mechanism

title: Refactor: Clear "that = this" pattern from codebase
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Acknowledge ALL below remarks -->
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Request may not be processed if it doesn't meet outlined criteria -->

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates  -->
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Plugin enhancements should be proposed at plugin repository, not here -->

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Answer ALL required questions below -->

<!--
Q1: Describe the problem (use case) that needs to be solved
-->

### Use case description

`that = this` Resembles questionable and heavily outdated pattern.

It was used before we had arrow functions, to maintain access to `this` across nested function references, with arrow functions `this` is shared and cases can be referenced directly

<!--
Q2: Propose solution (e.g. provide configuration example)

Note: This is optional, remove this section if you do not wish to propose anything at this point
-->

### Proposed solution

Simply remove `const that = this` and replace all `that` references with `this` (mind eventual non-arrow function expressions which rely on top level `that` if there are any upgrade them to arrow functions)
author: medikoo

comments.body: Hello, I am new to contributing. I am not well versed in JavaScript, though I would like to help with this issue since it seems to be a simple find and replace. Could you guide me through this issue?

@MatthewBerk it's simply about searching for `that = this` and clearing this out.

Anyway it was already perfectly addressed by @telenord you may check the PR

satisfaction_conditions: Eliminates all instances of the 'that = this' pattern from the codebase
Ensures correct handling of 'this' context in nested functions
Solution is accessible to contributors with varying JavaScript expertise
Does not introduce regressions in functionality

title: Custom authorizer for websockets connection not passing claims to next function and calling $disconnect rather than $connect
author: mrowles

comments.body: thanks for reporting @mrowles ... I'm guessing you're using Cognito?

> I have even tried separating the `$connect` & `$disconnect` handlers and it keeps sending it to the $disconnect:


We have the same result as you, for some reason a Custom Authoriser trigger Disconnect rather then Connect. We also tried to split connect and disconnect to separate handlers but to no avail, it still trigger disconnect.

**UPDATE:**
It was our fault. When i rewrote our custom authorizer to async await rather than promise().then() it started to work. The fault was probably something like the lambda terminated before the callback(null, policy) had finnished.
This was awesome @Denjul! I was missing the policy effect being passed back. Thanks for the assistance :)

satisfaction_conditions: Explanation of how to structure a custom authorizer response to trigger $connect instead of $disconnect
Clarification of required policy document structure in authorizer response
Demonstration of proper claims passing through authorizer context
Guidance on async/await vs promise/callback patterns in authorizer implementation
Explanation of relationship between authorizer response and WebSocket route selection

title: Bug: Rollback fails due to timestamp parsing error
body:
# This is a Bug Report

## Description

* What went wrong?
Receiving _Range Error: Invalid time value_ when trying to rollback (with correct timestamp).
E.g. _sls rollback -t 1546961025152_

* What did you expect should have happened?
Rollback should have been successful
Looks like since this.options.timestamp is a string, the wrong constructor of Date is called, and it's expecting a date string.
I was able to make this work by changing line 68 of _serverless\lib\plugins\aws\rollback\index.js_ to

      const date = new Date(Number(this.options.timestamp));

* What was the config you used?
Any, including the aws-java-gradle template

* What stacktrace or error message from your provider did you see?
  
Similar or dependent issues:

## Additional Data

* ***Serverless Framework Version you're using***: 1.35.1
* ***Operating System***: Windows 10 Enterprise (10.0.17134)
* ***Stack Trace***:

      RangeError: Invalid time value
          at Date.toISOString (<anonymous>)
          at provider.request.then (C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\serverless\lib\plugins\aws\rollback\index.js:69:65)
      From previous event:
          at AwsRollback.setStackToUpdate (C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\serverless\lib\plugins\aws\rollback\index.js:59:8)
      From previous event:
          at Object.rollback:rollback [as hook] (C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\serverless\lib\plugins\aws\rollback\index.js:40:12)
          at BbPromise.reduce (C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\serverless\lib\classes\PluginManager.js:391:55)
      From previous event:
          at PluginManager.invoke (C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\serverless\lib\classes\PluginManager.js:391:22)
          at PluginManager.run (C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\serverless\lib\classes\PluginManager.js:422:17)
          at variables.populateService.then.then (C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\serverless\lib\Serverless.js:157:33)
          at runCallback (timers.js:705:18)
          at tryOnImmediate (timers.js:676:5)
          at processImmediate (timers.js:658:5)
          at process.topLevelDomainCallback (domain.js:120:23)
      From previous event:
          at Serverless.run (C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\serverless\lib\Serverless.js:144:8)
          at serverless.init.then (C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\serverless\bin\serverless:44:28)

* ***Provider Error messages***:
author: ldani7492

comments.body: @ldani7492 Can you check if the PR i've just created fix your issue?
@luanmuniz it does, thank you

satisfaction_conditions: Resolve timestamp parsing errors during rollback operations
Maintain backward compatibility with existing timestamp formats
Validate solution works across different environment configurations

title: Unresolved config variables when passed to plugin
body:
# This is a Bug Report

## Description
Variables in the `serverless.yml` are not resolved when passed in to my custom plugin.

### What went wrong?
```yaml
service: test-service

plugins:
  - myCustomPlugin

custom:
  myPluginConfig:
    name: ${opt:stage}-${self:service}
```

In my plugin class constructor, `serverless.service.custom.myPluginConfig.name` is an actual string that holds `${opt:stage}-${self:service}`

### What did you expect should have happened?
The config variables to be resolved.

## Additional Data

* ***Serverless Framework Version you're using***: 1.21.1
author: b04zdotcom

comments.body:
Thank you for opening this issue @boazdejong !
Could you share your plugins source code or tell us the place which is stored so that taking a look into it?

@horike37 Sorry, but that's not possible. It is not part of an open source project.

I don't think the issue is related to the plugin though. It's just a class that receives unresolved variables as part of the `serverless` parameter.
@HyperBrain That was indeed what caused the problem, thank you for your help!
@boazdejong You're welcome 😃

> @HyperBrain That was indeed what caused the problem, thank you for your help!

Great @boazdejong 👍. Thanks for confirming!

Thanks for helping out @HyperBrain and @horike37 💯

satisfaction_conditions: Explanation of Serverless Framework's variable resolution timing in plugin lifecycle
Guidance on proper plugin initialization sequence for resolved variables
Clarification of Serverless's internal processing stages for variable substitution
Best practices for accessing resolved configuration in custom plugins

title: S3 bucket event does not create bucket as documented
body:
# This is a Bug Report

## Description

For bug reports:
* What went wrong?
Creating an S3 event didn't create the S3 bucket as documented.  The lambda is there but no S3 bucket at all.

* What did you expect should have happened?
The S3 bucket would be created as documented.

* What was the config you used?
```
service: my-service
provider:
  name: aws
  runtime: java8
  profile: myprofile
  region: us-west-2
  stage: dev
package:
  artifact: build/distributions/my-service-1.0-SNAPSHOT.zip
functions:
  myService:
    handler: codes.rik.myservice.MyServiceHandler
    events:
          - s3:
            bucket: photos
```

Similar or dependent issues:
* #3851

## Additional Data

* ***Serverless Framework Version you're using***: 1.21.0
* ***Operating System***: OS X
author: rikbrown

comments.body:
Thank you for opening up this issue @rikbrown  😊

Seems that the indent under `- s3` go wrong. that need more space.
Could you fix the serverless.yml syntax as follow and try again?

```yaml
- s3:
    bucket: photos
```

You're right: this was YAML indentation related.  Sigh, sorry.
I'll close this report, but if there's any future change you'd consider to at least be more defensive over this ("hey, you're an idiot like Rik who didn't indent properly, this isn't gonna work") I'd +1 it.

Cheers.

Thanks for opening @rikbrown and thanks for helping @horike37 👍

Glad to hear that the issue was resolved. Yes, this indentation is a little bit tricky. It's even worse when you copy and paste code snippets from tutorials and stuff. Ran into this a couple of times 😬...

Helping here (showing better error messages) is on our radar!

satisfaction_conditions: Validates YAML syntax and indentation requirements for S3 event configuration
Provides clear error messaging for configuration validation failures
Ensures S3 bucket creation aligns with documented behavior when properly configured
Addresses common YAML formatting pitfalls in Serverless Framework configurations
